RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-560, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=19307311; DOI=10.1128/MCB.01633-08;
RA   Wang X., Chinnam M., Wang J., Wang Y., Zhang X., Marcon E., Moens P.,
RA   Goodrich D.W.;
RT   "Thoc1 deficiency compromises gene expression necessary for normal
RT   testis development in the mouse.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 29:2794-2803(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for efficient export of polyadenylated RNA.
CC       Acts as component of the THO subcomplex of the TREX complex which
CC       is thought to couple mRNA transcription, processing and nuclear
CC       export, and which specifically associates with spliced mRNA and
CC       not with unspliced pre-mRNA. TREX is recruited to spliced mRNAs by
CC       a transcription-independent mechanism, binds to mRNA upstream of
CC       the exon-junction complex (EJC) and is recruited in a splicing-
CC       and cap-dependent manner to a region near the 5' end of the mRNA
CC       where it functions in mRNA export to the cytoplasm via the
CC       TAP/NFX1 pathway. Regulates transcriptional elongation of a subset
CC       of genes. Involved in genome stability by preventing co-
CC       transcriptional R-loop formation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Participates in an apoptotic pathway which is
CC       characterized by activation of caspase-6, increases in the
CC       expression of BAK1 and BCL2L1 and activation of NF-kappa-B. This
CC       pathway does not require p53/TP53, nor does the presence of
CC       p53/TP53 affect the efficiency of cell killing. Activates a G2/M
CC       cell cycle checkpoint prior to the onset of apoptosis. Apoptosis
CC       is inhibited by association with RB1 (By similarity). Essential
CC       for early embryonic development. Required for normal gene
CC       expression during postnatal testis development. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16705185, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19307311}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the THO complex, which is composed of THOC1,
CC       THOC2, THOC3, THOC5, THOC6 and THOC7; together with at least
CC       ALYREF/THOC4, DDX39B, SARNP/CIP29 and CHTOP, THO forms the
CC       transcription/export (TREX) complex which seems to have a dynamic
CC       structure involving ATP-dependent remodeling. Binds to the
CC       hypophosphorylated form of RB1. Interacts with THOC2, THOC5,
CC       DDX39B and RNA polymerase II. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16909111}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus speckle {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus,
CC       nucleoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16705185}. Nucleus matrix
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Note=Can shuttle between
CC       the nucleus and cytoplasm. Nuclear localization is required for
CC       induction of apoptotic cell death. Translocates to the cytoplasm
CC       during the early phase of apoptosis execution (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Widely expressed during embryonic
CC       development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16705185}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: An intact death domain is needed for apoptosis.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Expression is altered specifically during apoptosis and is
CC       accompanied by the appearance of novel forms with smaller apparent
CC       molecular mass. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Polyubiquitinated, leading to proteasomal degradation;
CC       probably involves NEDD4. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice show early embryonic lethality and
CC       severely diminished fertility. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16705185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19307311}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 death domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00064}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of a multi-subunit complex involved in
CC       microtubule based vesicle motility. It is associated with the
CC       centrosome (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, microtubule organizing center, centrosome
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the actin family. ARP1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RT   and cell motility through interaction with GEF-H1.";
RL   J. Cell Sci. 124:1214-1223(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Activates Rho-GTPases by promoting the exchange of GDP
CC       for GTP. May be involved in epithelial barrier permeability, cell
CC       motility and polarization, dendritic spine morphology, antigen
CC       presentation, leukemic cell differentiation, cell cycle
CC       regulation, innate immune response, and cancer. Binds Rac-GTPases,
CC       but does not seem to promote nucleotide exchange activity toward
CC       Rac-GTPases. May stimulate instead the cortical activity of Rac.
CC       Inactive toward CDC42, TC10, or Ras-GTPases. Forms an
CC       intracellular sensing system along with NOD1 for the detection of
CC       microbial effectors during cell invasion by pathogens. Involved in
CC       innate immune signaling transduction pathway promoting cytokine
CC       IL6/interleukin-6 and TNF-alpha secretion in macrophage upon
CC       stimulation by bacterial peptidoglycans; acts as a signaling
CC       intermediate between NOD2 receptor and RIPK2 kinase. Contributes
CC       to the tyrosine phosphorylation of RIPK2 through Src tyrosine
CC       kinase leading to NF-kappaB activation by NOD2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Found in a complex composed at least of ARHGEF2, NOD2 and
CC       RIPK2. Interacts with RIPK2; the interaction mediates tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation of RIPK2 by Src kinase CSK. Interacts with RIPK1
CC       and RIPK3. Interacts with YWHAZ/14-3-3 zeta; when phosphorylated
CC       at Ser-885. Interacts with the kinases PAK4, AURKA and MAPK1.
CC       Interacts with RHOA and RAC1. Interacts with NOD1 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts (via the N- terminal zinc finger) with CAPN6 (via domain
CC       II). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21406564}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q61097:Ksr1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-772191, EBI-1536336;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction,
CC       tight junction {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12604587}. Golgi apparatus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, spindle {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cytoplasmic vesicle {ECO:0000250}. Note=Localizes to the tips of
CC       cortical microtubules of the mitotic spindle during cell division,
CC       and is further released upon microtubule depolymerization.
CC       Colocalized with NOD2 and RIPK2 in vesicles and with the
CC       cytoskeleton (By similarity). Associated with apical intercellular
CC       junctions in the trophectoderm of the blastocyst. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-2; Sequence=VSP_022641;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-3; Sequence=VSP_022640, VSP_022642, VSP_022643;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-4; Sequence=VSP_034962;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-5; Sequence=VSP_034962, VSP_034963;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitous, with the exception of liver
CC       tissue. Levels are high in hemopoietic tissues (thymus, spleen,
CC       bone marrow) as well as in kidney and lung.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The DH (DBL-homology) domain promotes tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation of RIPK2 (By similarity). The DH (DBL-homology)
CC       domain interacts with and promotes loading of GTP on RhoA.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PH (pleckstrin-homology) domain is involved in
CC       microtubule binding and targeting to tight junctions.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Ser-885 by PAK1 induces binding to protein
CC       YWHAZ, promoting its relocation to microtubules and the inhibition
CC       of its activity. Phosphorylated by AURKA and CDK1 during mitosis,
CC       which negatively regulates its activity. Phosphorylation by MAPK1
CC       or MAPK3 increases nucleotide exchange activity. Phosphorylation
CC       by PAK4 releases GEF-H1 from the microtubules. Phosphorylated on
CC       serine, threonine and tyrosine residues in a RIPK2-dependent
CC       manner (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 DH (DBL-homology) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00062}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PH domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00145}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 phorbol-ester/DAG-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00226}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BAC41438.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for mitochondrial complex I assembly (By
CC       similarity). Has a dehydrogenase activity on palmitoyl-CoA (C16:0)
CC       and stearoyl-CoA (C18:0). It is three times more active on
CC       palmitoyl-CoA then on stearoyl-CoA. However, it does not play a
CC       primary role in long-chain fatty acid oxidation (By similarity).
CC       Has little activity on octanoyl-CoA (C8:0), butyryl-CoA (C4:0) or
CC       isovaleryl-CoA (5:0) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H845}.

CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Part of the mitochondrial complex I assembly (MCIA)
CC       complex. The complex comprises at least TMEM126B, NDUFAF1, ECSIT,
CC       and ACAD9 (By similarity). Interacts with NDUFAF1 and ECSIT (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9H845}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for distribution of pericentromeric
CC       heterochromatin in interphase nuclei and for centromere formation
CC       and organization, chromosome alignment and cytokinesis.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Chromosome, centromere, kinetochore
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton,
CC       spindle {ECO:0000250}. Note=Enriched at the nuclear periphery and
CC       around the nucleolus. In mitotic cells, localizes to kinetochores
CC       from prometaphase to metaphase. At anaphase onset, transfers to
CC       the spindle midzone and then to the mid-body in telophase and
CC       cytokinesis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

RN   [10]
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, SUBUNIT, ENZYME REGULATION, INTERACTION
RP   WITH MID1IP1, PHOSPHORYLATION AT SER-79, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=20952656; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1012736107;
RA   Colbert C.L., Kim C.W., Moon Y.A., Henry L., Palnitkar M.,
RA   McKean W.B., Fitzgerald K., Deisenhofer J., Horton J.D., Kwon H.J.;
RT   "Crystal structure of Spot 14, a modulator of fatty acid synthesis.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:18820-18825(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the rate-limiting reaction in the biogenesis
CC       of long-chain fatty acids. Carries out three functions: biotin
CC       carboxyl carrier protein, biotin carboxylase and
CC       carboxyltransferase. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13085}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + acetyl-CoA + HCO(3)(-) = ADP + phosphate
CC       + malonyl-CoA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20952656}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + biotin-[carboxyl-carrier-protein] +
CC       HCO(3)(-) = ADP + phosphate + carboxy-biotin-[carboxyl-carrier-
CC       protein]. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20952656}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=biotin; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57586;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O00763};
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29035; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 2 manganese ions per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: By phosphorylation (By similarity). Activity is
CC       increased by oligomerization. Citrate and MID1IP1 promote
CC       oligomerization. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20952656}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Lipid metabolism; malonyl-CoA biosynthesis; malonyl-CoA
CC       from acetyl-CoA: step 1/1.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer, homodimer, and homotetramer. Can form
CC       filamentous polymers. Interacts in its inactive phosphorylated
CC       form with the BRCT domains of BRCA1 which prevents ACACA
CC       dephosphorylation and inhibits lipid synthesis. Interacts with
CC       MID1IP1; interaction with MID1IP1 promotes oligomerization and
CC       increases its activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12360400,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20952656}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12360400,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20952656}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative promoter usage; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q5SWU9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q5SWU9-2; Sequence=VSP_026101;
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation on Ser-1262 is required for interaction with
CC       BRCA1. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13085}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 ATP-grasp domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00409}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 biotin carboxylation domain. {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 biotinyl-binding domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01066}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 carboxyltransferase domain. {ECO:0000255}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the chromosomal passenger complex (CPC), a
CC       complex that acts as a key regulator of mitosis. The CPC complex
CC       has essential functions at the centromere in ensuring correct
CC       chromosome alignment and segregation and is required for
CC       chromatin-induced microtubule stabilization and spindle assembly.
CC       Probably acts through association with AURKB or AURKC. Seems to
CC       bind directly to microtubules. Controls the kinetochore
CC       localization of BUB1 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer or heterodimer (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       CDCA8 and BIRC5; interaction is direct (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with CBX3. Interacts with tubulin beta chain. Interacts with AURKB
CC       and AURKC. Component of the CPC at least composed of
CC       BIRC5/survivin, CDCA8/borealin, INCENP and AURKB/Aurora-B.
CC       Interacts with EVI5 (By similarity). Interacts with H2AFZ (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with H2AFZ. Interacts with CBX5; POGZ and
CC       INCENP compete for interaction with CBX5. Interacts with POGZ.
CC       Interacts with JTB (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Chromosome, centromere
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12584241}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, spindle
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12584241}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12584241}. Chromosome, centromere, kinetochore
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12584241}. Note=Localizes to inner
CC       kinetochore. Localizes on chromosome arms and inner centromeres
CC       from prophase through metaphase and then transferring to the
CC       spindle midzone and midbody from anaphase through cytokinesis.
CC       Localized at synaptonemal complex central element from zygotene up
CC       to late pachytene when it begins to relocalize to heterochromatic
CC       chromocenters. Colocalizes with AURKB at a connecting strand
CC       traversing the centromere region and joining sister kinetochores,
CC       in metaphase II centromeres. This strand disappears at the
CC       metaphase II/anaphase II transition and relocalizes to the spindle
CC       midzone.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=B;
CC         IsoId=Q9WU62-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Major isoform in thymic lymphoma 3SB cells. Fourfold more
CC         abundant than isoform 2.;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q9WU62-2; Sequence=VSP_007233;
CC         Note=Minor isoform in thymic lymphoma 3SB cells.;
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation by AURKB at its C-terminal part is important
CC       for AURKB activation by INCENP. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the INCENP family. {ECO:0000305}.

RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA

RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [3]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.25 ANGSTROMS) OF 183-585 IN COMPLEX WITH ADP
RP   AND ATP ANALOG, FUNCTION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF LYS-293; VAL-294 AND
RP   ASP-295.
RX   PubMed=14980225; DOI=10.1016/S0092-8674(04)00129-1;
RA   Ogawa T., Nitta R., Okada Y., Hirokawa N.;
RT   "A common mechanism for microtubule destabilizers-M type kinesins
RT   stabilize curling of the protofilament using the class-specific neck
RT   and loops.";
RL   Cell 116:591-602(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: In complex with KIF18B, constitutes the major
CC       microtubule plus-end depolymerizing activity in mitotic cells.
CC       Regulates the turnover of microtubules at the kinetochore and
CC       functions in chromosome segregation during mitosis. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CENPH. Interacts with MTUS2/TIP150; the
CC       interaction is direct. Interacts with MAPRE1; the interaction is
CC       direct, regulated by phosphorylation and is probably required for
CC       targeting to growing microtubule plus ends (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with KIF18B at microtubule tips; this interaction
CC       increases the affinity of both partners for microtubule plus ends
CC       and is required for robust microtubule depolymerization.
CC       Phosphorylation by AURKA or AURKB strongly reduces KIF18B-binding
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Chromosome, centromere {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Chromosome, centromere, kinetochore {ECO:0000250}. Note=Associates
CC       with the microtubule network at the growing distal tip (the plus-
CC       end) of microtubules, probably through interaction with
CC       MTUS2/TIP150 and MAPRE1. Association with microtubule plus ends is
CC       also mediated by interaction with KIF18B (By similarity).
CC       Centromeric localization requires the presence of BUB1 and SGOL2
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The microtubule tip localization signal (MtLS) motif;
CC       mediates interaction with MAPRE1 and targeting to the growing
CC       microtubule plus ends. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation by AURKB, regulates association with
CC       centromeres and kinetochores and the microtubule depolymerization
CC       activity. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class myosin-kinesin ATPase
CC       superfamily. Kinesin family. MCAK/KIF2 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00283}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 kinesin motor domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00283}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic

RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein promotes the GTP-dependent binding of
CC       aminoacyl-tRNA to the A-site of ribosomes during protein
CC       biosynthesis. With PARP1 and TXK, forms a complex that acts as a T
CC       helper 1 (Th1) cell-specific transcription factor and binds the
CC       promoter of IFN-gamma to directly regulate its transcription, and
CC       is thus involved importantly in Th1 cytokine production (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Found in a nuclear export complex with XPO5, EEF1A1, Ran
CC       and aminoacylated tRNA. Interacts with PARP1, TXK, XPO5 and KARS
CC       (By similarity). May interact with ERGIC2 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with DLC1, facilitating distribution to the membrane
CC       periphery and ruffles upon growth factor stimulation (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with ZPR1; the interaction occurs in a
CC       epidermal growth factor (EGF)-dependent manner (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with IFIT1 (via TPR repeats 4-7). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19856081}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01534:TSPY1 (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-773865, EBI-1973142;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19856081}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Colocalizes with DLC1 at actin-rich regions in the cell
CC       periphery. Translocates together with ZPR1 from the cytoplasm to
CC       the nucleus and nucleolus after treatment with mitogens (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: ISGylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16139798}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by TXK. Phosphorylation by PASK increases
CC       translation efficiency (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Classic translation factor GTPase family. EF-Tu/EF-1A
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 tr-type G (guanine nucleotide-binding)
CC       domain. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [8]
RP   INTERACTION WITH PIK3CB.
RX   PubMed=21059846; DOI=10.1083/jcb.201006056;
RA   Dou Z., Chattopadhyay M., Pan J.-A., Guerriero J.L., Jiang Y.-P.,
RA   Ballou L.M., Yue Z., Lin R.Z., Zong W.-X.;
RT   "The class IA phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase p110-beta subunit is a
RT   positive regulator of autophagy.";
RL   J. Cell Biol. 191:827-843(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The small GTPases Rab are key regulators of
CC       intracellular membrane trafficking, from the formation of
CC       transport vesicles to their fusion with membranes. Rabs cycle
CC       between an inactive GDP-bound form and an active GTP-bound form
CC       that is able to recruit to membranes different sets of downstream
CC       effectors directly responsible for vesicle formation, movement,
CC       tethering and fusion. RAB5A is required for the fusion of plasma
CC       membranes and early endosomes. Contributes to the regulation of
CC       filopodia extension (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Regulated by guanine nucleotide exchange
CC       factors (GEFs) which promote the exchange of bound GDP for free
CC       GTP.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with GDI1; this promotes dissociation from
CC       membranes. Interacts with EEA1. Interacts with RIN1 and GAPVD1,
CC       which regulate its pathway, probably by acting as a GEF. Interacts
CC       with RINL. Interacts with ALS2CL, SUN2, ZFYVE20 and RUFY1.
CC       Interacts with RABEP1; one RABEP1 homodimer binds two RAB5A
CC       chains, but at opposite sides of the dimer (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with SGSM1 and SGSM3. Interacts with PIK3CB.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17509819,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21059846}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Lipid-anchor
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Early endosome
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Lipid-anchor {ECO:0000250}. Melanosome
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle {ECO:0000250}. Cell projection,
CC       ruffle {ECO:0000250}. Membrane {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytosol
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Alternates between membrane-bound and
CC       cytosolic forms. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the small GTPase superfamily. Rab family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the overall
CC       conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and CO(2), and thereby links
CC       the glycolytic pathway to the tricarboxylic cycle. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyruvate + [dihydrolipoyllysine-residue
CC       acetyltransferase] lipoyllysine = [dihydrolipoyllysine-residue
CC       acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine + CO(2).
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=thiamine diphosphate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:58937;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of two PDHA1 and two PDHB subunits. The
CC       heterotetramer interacts with DLAT, and is part of the multimeric
CC       pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that contains multiple copies of
CC       pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1), dihydrolipoamide acetyltransferase
CC       (DLAT, E2) and lipoamide dehydrogenase (DLD, E3). These subunits
CC       are bound to an inner core composed of about 48 DLAT and 12 PDHX
CC       molecules (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion matrix {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH02188.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Core component of multiple cullin-RING-based BCR (BTB-
CC       CUL3-RBX1) E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase complexes which mediate the
CC       ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation of target
CC       proteins. As a scaffold protein may contribute to catalysis
CC       through positioning of the substrate and the ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme. The E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase activity of the complex is
CC       dependent on the neddylation of the cullin subunit and is
CC       inhibited by the association of the deneddylated cullin subunit
CC       with TIP120A/CAND1 (By similarity). The functional specificity of
CC       the BCR complex depends on the BTB domain-containing protein as
CC       the substrate recognition component. BCR(KLHL42) is involved in
CC       ubiquitination of KATNA1. BCR(SPOP) is involved in ubiquitination
CC       of BMI1/PCGF4, BRMS1, H2AFY and DAXX, GLI2 and GLI3. Can also form
CC       a cullin-RING-based BCR (BTB-CUL3-RBX1) E3 ubiquitin-protein
CC       ligase complex containing homodimeric SPOPL or the heterodimer
CC       formed by SPOP and SPOPL; these complexes have lower ubiquitin
CC       ligase activity. BCR(KLHL9-KLHL13) controls the dynamic behavior
CC       of AURKB on mitotic chromosomes and thereby coordinates faithful
CC       mitotic progression and completion of cytokinesis. BCR(KLHL3) acts
CC       as a regulator of ion transport in the distal nephron; by
CC       mediating ubiquitination of WNK4. The BCR(KLHL20) E3 ubiquitin
CC       ligase complex is involved in interferon response and anterograde
CC       Golgi to endosome transport: it mediates both ubiquitination
CC       leading to degradation and 'Lys-33'-linked ubiquitination. The
CC       BCR(KLHL21) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex regulates localization of
CC       the chromosomal passenger complex (CPC) from chromosomes to the
CC       spindle midzone in anaphase and mediates the ubiquitination of
CC       AURKB. The BCR(KLHL22) ubiquitin ligase complex mediates
CC       monoubiquitination of PLK1, leading to PLK1 dissociation from
CC       phosphoreceptor proteins and subsequent removal from kinetochores,
CC       allowing silencing of the spindle assembly checkpoint (SAC) and
CC       chromosome segregation. The BCR(KLHL25) ubiquitin ligase complex
CC       is involved in translational homeostasis by mediating
CC       ubiquitination and subsequent degradation of hypophosphorylated
CC       EIF4EBP1 (4E-BP1). Involved in ubiquitination of cyclin E and of
CC       cyclin D1 (in vitro) thus involved in regulation of G1/S
CC       transition (By similarity). Involved in the ubiquitination of
CC       KEAP1, ENC1 and KLHL41. BCR(KLHL12) is involved in ER-Golgi
CC       transport by regulating the size of COPII coats, thereby playing a
CC       key role in collagen export, which is required for embryonic stem
CC       (ES) cells division: BCR(KLHL12) acts by mediating
CC       monoubiquitination of SEC31 (SEC31A or SEC31B). In concert with
CC       ATF2 and RBX1, promotes degradation of KAT5 thereby attenuating
CC       its ability to acetylate and activate ATM (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms neddylation-dependent homodimers. Component of
CC       multiple BCR (BTB-CUL3-RBX1) E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase complexes
CC       formed of CUL3, RBX1 and a variable BTB domain-containing protein
CC       acting as both, adapter to cullin and substrate recognition
CC       subunit. The BCR complex may be active as a heterodimeric complex,
CC       in which NEDD8, covalently attached to one CUL3 molecule, binds to
CC       the C-terminus of a second CUL3 molecule. Interacts with RBX1,
CC       RNF7, CYCE and TIP120A/CAND1. Part of the BCR(SPOP) containing
CC       SPOP, and of BCR containing homodimeric SPOPL or the heterodimer
CC       formed by SPOP and SPOPL. Component of the BCR(KLHL21) E3
CC       ubiquitin ligase complex, at least composed of CUL3, KLHL21 and
CC       RBX1. Component of the BCR(KLHL22) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, at
CC       least composed of CUL3, KLHL22 and RBX1. Component of the
CC       BCR(KLHL25) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, at least composed of
CC       CUL3, KLHL25 and RBX1. Part of the probable BCR(KLHL9-KLHL13)
CC       complex with BTB domain proteins KLHL9 and KLHL13. Part of the
CC       BCR(KLHL41) complex containing KLHL41. Component of the
CC       BCR(KLHL12) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, at least composed of CUL3
CC       and KLHL12 and RBX1. Component of the BCR(KLHL3) E3 ubiquitin
CC       ligase complex, at least composed of CUL3 and KLHL3 and RBX1
CC       (Probable). Part of the BCR(ENC1) complex containing ENC1. Part of
CC       a complex consisting of BMI1/PCGF4, CUL3 and SPOP. Part of a
CC       complex consisting of BRMS1, CUL3 and SPOP. Part of a complex
CC       consisting of H2AFY, CUL3 and SPOP. Component of the BCR(KLHL42)
CC       E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, at least composed of CUL3 and KLHL42.
CC       Interacts with KLHL42 (via the BTB domain). Interacts with KATNA1;
CC       the interaction is enhanced by KLHL42. Interacts with KCTD5,
CC       KLHL9, KLHL11, KLHL13, GAN, ZBTB16, KLHL3, KLHL15, KLHL20, KLHL36,
CC       GMCL1P1, BTBD1. Part of a complex that contains CUL3, RBX1 and
CC       GAN. Interacts (via BTB domain) with KLHL17; the interaction
CC       regulates surface GRIK2 expression. Interacts with KCTD7. Part of
CC       the BCR(GAN) complex containing GAN. Part of the BCR(KEAP1)
CC       complex containing KEAP1 (By similarity). Interacts with KLHL10.
CC       Interacts with KAT5 and ATF2 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10500095}. Golgi
CC       apparatus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10500095}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed, with highest expression in
CC       brain, spleen and testis. In the testis, it is mainly expressed in
CC       spermatids. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10500095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16162871}.
CC   -!- PTM: Neddylated. Attachment of NEDD8 is required for the E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase activity of the BCR E3 ligase complex.
CC       Deneddylated via its interaction with the COP9 signalosome (CSN)
CC       complex (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Null deficient mice are not viable.
CC       Extraembryonic ectoderm shows a greatly increased number of cells
CC       in S phase. In the trophectoderm cells are blocked to entry into S
CC       phase. Embryonic stem (ES) cells form tightly packed cell clusters
CC       with prominent actin cables and aberrant adhesions. ES cells are
CC       retained in proliferation, yet retain their pluripotency.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10500095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22358839}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cullin family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00330}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.8 ANGSTROMS), DOMAIN ARCHITECTURE,
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-44; LYS-45 AND ARG-48, FHA DOMAIN, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=15749016; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2005.02.012;
RA   Bernstein N.K., Williams R.S., Rakovszky M.L., Cui D., Green R.,
RA   Karimi-Busheri F., Mani R.S., Galicia S., Koch C.A., Cass C.E.,
RA   Durocher D., Weinfeld M., Glover J.N.;
RT   "The molecular architecture of the mammalian DNA repair enzyme,
RT   polynucleotide kinase.";
RL   Mol. Cell 17:657-670(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a key role in the repair of DNA damage,
CC       functioning as part of both the non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ)
CC       and base excision repair (BER) pathways. Through its two catalytic
CC       activities, PNK ensures that DNA termini are compatible with
CC       extension and ligation by either removing 3'-phosphates from, or
CC       by phosphorylating 5'-hydroxyl groups on, the ribose sugar of the
CC       DNA backbone.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 3'-phosphopolynucleotide + H(2)O = a
CC       polynucleotide + phosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + 5'-dephospho-DNA = ADP + 5'-phospho-DNA.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15749016}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9JLV6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9JLV6-2; Sequence=VSP_010771;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The FHA domain binds threonine-phosphorylated peptides
CC       from XRCC1/4, and is responsible for the recruitment of PNKP to
CC       the sites of DNA repair. The affinity is ten times greater if
CC       peptides are also phosphorylated on the serine preceeding the
CC       phosphothreonine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15749016}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the DNA 3'
CC       phosphatase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 FHA domain. {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Eye;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [4]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA] OF 35-794, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, AND
RP   INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=9626505;
RX   DOI=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0177(199806)212:2<304::AID-AJA15>3.3.CO;2-Z;
RA   Sam M., Wurst W., Klueppel M., Jin O., Heng H., Bernstein A.;
RT   "Aquarius, a novel gene isolated by gene trapping with an RNA-
RT   dependent RNA polymerase motif.";
RL   Dev. Dyn. 212:304-317(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Intron-binding spliceosomal protein required to link
CC       pre-mRNA splicing and snoRNP (small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein)
CC       biogenesis. Plays a key role in position-dependent assembly of
CC       intron-encoded box C/D small snoRNP, splicing being required for
CC       snoRNP assembly. May act by helping the folding of the snoRNA
CC       sequence. Binds to intron of pre-mRNAs in a sequence-independent
CC       manner, contacting the region between snoRNA and the branchpoint
CC       of introns (40 nucleotides upstream of the branchpoint) during the
CC       late stages of splicing. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60306}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Identified in the spliceosome C complex. Component of the
CC       XAB2 complex, a multimeric protein complex composed of XAB2,
CC       PRPF19, AQR, ZNF830, ISY1, and PPIE.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60306}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60306}.
CC       Note=Localizes to speckle-like regions of the nucleoplasm.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60306}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: First detected at 8.5 dpc, when neural crest
CC       cells are visible at the lateral ridges of the neural plate.
CC       During embryogenesis, it is expressed in mesoderm, in the neural
CC       crest (and its target tissues) and in neuroepithelium.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9626505}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By retinoic acid (RA). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9626505}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CWF11 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB50008.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=Several; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAC65592.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-1382, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19144319; DOI=10.1016/j.immuni.2008.11.006;

RA   Thibault P.;
RT   "The phagosomal proteome in interferon-gamma-activated macrophages.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Major 5'-3' exoribonuclease involved in mRNA decay.
CC       Required for the 5'-3'-processing of the G4 tetraplex-containing
CC       DNA and RNA substrates. The kinetic of hydrolysis is faster for G4
CC       RNA tetraplex than for G4 DNA tetraplex and monomeric RNA
CC       tetraplex. Binds to RNA and DNA. Plays a role in replication-
CC       dependent histone mRNA degradation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Found in a mRNP complex with UPF1, UPF2, UPF3B and XRN1.
CC       Interacts with DIS3L2 (By similarity). Associates with alpha and
CC       beta tubulins. Interacts with ZC3HAV1 in an RNA-dependent manner
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9049243}.
CC       Note=Discrete foci at the inner surface of the cell membrane.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P97789-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P97789-2; Sequence=VSP_016697;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P97789-3; Sequence=VSP_016696, VSP_016698;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in heart, brain (spinal cord, dorsal
CC       root and superior cervical ganglia, neurons of the cerebrum and
CC       brain stem), peripheral nerve fibers in the skin and intestine,
CC       spleen, lung, liver, skeletal muscle, kidney and testis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14580940, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9049243,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9218715}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in embryo between 7 and 17 dpc.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14580940}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 5'-3' exonuclease family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Displays temperature-dependent chaperone activity.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. Interacts with HSPB1 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with DNAJB6 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Translocates to nuclear foci during heat
CC       shock. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in skeletal muscle, heart,
CC       uterus, liver, lung and ovary. Low levels found in stomach and
CC       brain. Not detected in small intestine, large intestine, kidney,
CC       spleen and testis. In the ovary, expression is concentrated in the
CC       endometrium and in the connective tissue between the circular and
CC       longitudinal muscles of the myometrium.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11133685}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected in developing heart throughout
CC       embryonic development but only detected in developing liver close
CC       to time of birth. In the adult ovary, expression is highest during
CC       decidualization and early pregnancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11133685}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By progesterone. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11133685}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the small heat shock protein (HSP20)
CC       family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00285}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May mediate the transduction of intracellular signals.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with DOCK2 and EPOR. Interacts with
CC       phosphorylated CBLB and IRS4 (By similarity). Interacts with

CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine. Phosphorylation is prominent
CC       during early development, but decreases at later embryonic stages
CC       and in newborn mice.

RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,

RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Lamins are components of the nuclear lamina, a fibrous
CC       layer on the nucleoplasmic side of the inner nuclear membrane,
CC       which is thought to provide a framework for the nuclear envelope
CC       and may also interact with chromatin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with lamin-associated polypeptides
CC       IA, IB and 2 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus inner membrane; Lipid-anchor;
CC       Nucleoplasmic side.
CC   -!- PTM: B-type lamins undergo a series of modifications, such as
CC       farnesylation and phosphorylation. Increased phosphorylation of
CC       the lamins occurs before envelope disintegration and probably
CC       plays a role in regulating lamin associations.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The structural integrity of the lamina is strictly
CC       controlled by the cell cycle, as seen by the disintegration and
CC       formation of the nuclear envelope in prophase and telophase,
CC       respectively.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the intermediate filament family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 LTD domain. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORMS 1 AND 2).
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6; TISSUE=Brain, and Mammary tumor;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;

RN   [4]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19144319; DOI=10.1016/j.immuni.2008.11.006;
RA   Trost M., English L., Lemieux S., Courcelles M., Desjardins M.,
RA   Thibault P.;
RT   "The phagosomal proteome in interferon-gamma-activated macrophages.";
RL   Immunity 30:143-154(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Core component of the splicing-dependent multiprotein
CC       exon junction complex (EJC) deposited at splice junctions on
CC       mRNAs. The EJC is a dynamic structure consisting of core proteins
CC       and several peripheral nuclear and cytoplasmic associated factors
CC       that join the complex only transiently either during EJC assembly
CC       or during subsequent mRNA metabolism. The EJC marks the position
CC       of the exon-exon junction in the mature mRNA for the gene
CC       expression machinery and the core components remain bound to
CC       spliced mRNAs throughout all stages of mRNA metabolism thereby
CC       influencing downstream processes including nuclear mRNA export,
CC       subcellular mRNA localization, translation efficiency and
CC       nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD). The MAGOH-RBM8A heterodimer
CC       inhibits the ATPase activity of EIF4A3, thereby trapping the ATP-
CC       bound EJC core onto spliced mRNA in a stable conformation. The
CC       MAGOH-RBM8A heterodimer interacts with the EJC key regulator
CC       WIBG/PYM leading to EJC disassembly in the cytoplasm and
CC       translation enhancement of EJC-bearing spliced mRNAs by recruiting
CC       them to the ribosomal 48S preinitiation complex. Its removal from
CC       cytoplasmic mRNAs requires translation initiation from EJC-bearing
CC       spliced mRNAs. Associates preferentially with mRNAs produced by
CC       splicing. Does not interact with pre-mRNAs, introns, or mRNAs
CC       produced from intronless cDNAs. Associates with both nuclear mRNAs
CC       and newly exported cytoplasmic mRNAs. The MAGOH-RBM8A heterodimer
CC       is a component of the nonsense mediated decay (NMD) pathway.
CC       Involved in the splicing modulation of BCL2L1/Bcl-X (and probably
CC       other apoptotic genes); specifically inhibits formation of
CC       proapoptotic isoforms; the function is different from the
CC       established EJC assembly (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer with RBM8A. Part of the mRNA splicing-
CC       dependent exon junction complex (EJC) complex; the core complex
CC       contains CASC3, EIF4A3, MAGOH and RBM8A. Interacts with WIBG/PYM;
CC       the interaction is direct and dissociates the EJC from spliced
CC       mRNAs. Found in a post-splicing complex with NXF1, RBM8A, UPF1,
CC       UPF2, UPF3A, UPF3B and RNPS1. Interacts with BAT1, MAGOH, OVCA1,
CC       UPF3B, RNPS1, SRRM1 and ALYREF/THOC4. Interacts with IPO13; the
CC       interaction mediates the nuclear import of the MAGOH-RBM8A
CC       heterodimer. Identified in the spliceosome C complex. Associates
CC       with polysomes (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus speckle
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Note=Nucleocytoplasmic
CC       shuttling protein. Travels to the cytoplasm as part of the exon
CC       junction complex (EJC) bound to mRNA. Colocalizes with the core
CC       EJC, ALYREF/THOC4, NXF1 and UAP56 in the nucleus and nuclear
CC       speckles (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9CWZ3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9CWZ3-2; Sequence=VSP_010251;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RBM8A family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 RRM (RNA recognition motif) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00176}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. {ECO:0000256|PIRNR:PIRNR003354}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits.
CC       {ECO:0000256|PIRNR:PIRNR003354}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000256|PIRNR:PIRNR003354}.
CC       Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000256|PIRNR:PIRNR003354};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000256|PIRNR:PIRNR003354}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Dipeptidyl peptidase that cleaves off N-terminal
CC       dipeptides from proteins having a Pro or Ala residue at position
CC       2. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Release of an N-terminal dipeptide, Xaa-Yaa-|-
CC       Zaa-, from a polypeptide, preferentially when Yaa is Pro, provided
CC       Zaa is neither Pro nor hydroxyproline.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by the serine proteinase inhibitor 4-
CC       (2-aminoethyl)benzenesulphonyl fluoride (AEBSF), and by di-
CC       isopropylfuorophosphate. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: PPIases accelerate the folding of proteins. It catalyzes
CC       the cis-trans isomerization of proline imidic peptide bonds in
CC       oligopeptides. May be implicated in the folding, transport, and
CC       assembly of proteins. May play an important role in the regulation
CC       of pre-mRNA splicing (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Peptidylproline (omega=180) = peptidylproline
CC       (omega=0).
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Cyclosporin A (CsA)-sensitive. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CLK1, PNN and with the phosphorylated C-
CC       terminal domain of RNA polymerase II. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus matrix. Nucleus speckle.
CC       Note=Colocalizes with splicing factors at nuclear speckles.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RS domain is required for the interaction with the
CC       phosphorylated C-terminal domain of RNA polymerase II.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PPIase cyclophilin-type domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00156}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Core component of multiple cullin-RING-based E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase complexes which mediate the
CC       ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation of target
CC       proteins. The functional specificity of the E3 ubiquitin-protein
CC       ligase complex depends on the variable substrate recognition
CC       subunit. CUL4B may act within the complex as a scaffold protein,
CC       contributing to catalysis through positioning of the substrate and
CC       the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme. Plays a role as part of the E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase complex in polyubiquitination of CDT1,
CC       histone H2A, histone H3 and histone H4 in response to radiation-
CC       induced DNA damage. Targeted to UV damaged chromatin by DDB2 and
CC       may be important for DNA repair and DNA replication. Required for
CC       ubiquitination of cyclin E, and consequently, normal G1 cell cycle
CC       progression. Regulates the mammalian target-of-rapamycin (mTOR)
CC       pathway involved in control of cell growth, size and metabolism.
CC       Specific CUL4B regulation of the mTORC1-mediated pathway is
CC       dependent upon 26S proteasome function and requires interaction
CC       between CUL4B and MLST8 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13620}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13620}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of multiple DCX (DDB1-CUL4-X-box) E3 ubiquitin-
CC       protein ligase complexes that seem to be formed of DDB1, CUL4A or
CC       CUL4B, RBX1 and a variable substrate recognition component which
CC       seems to belong to a protein family described as DCAF (Ddb1- and
CC       Cul4-associated factor) or CDW (CUL4-DDB1-associated WD40-repeat)
CC       proteins. Component of the DCX(DTL) complex with the putative
CC       substrate recognition component DTL. Component of the DCX(DDB2)
CC       complex with the putative substrate recognition component DDB2.
CC       Part of a complex with RBX1 and TIP120A/CAND1. Interacts with RBX1
CC       GRWD1, MLST8, SMU1, TLE2, TLE3, VPRBP, DDA1, DCAF6, DCAF17, DDB2,
CC       DCAF8, TIP120A/CAND1 and TMEM113. Interacts with cyclin E and with
CC       importins alpha-1 (KPNA2), alpha-3 (KPNA4), alpha-5 (KPNA1) and
CC       beta-1 (KPNB1). May interact with WDR26, WDR51B, SNRNP40, WDR61,
CC       WDR76 and WDR5 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13620}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13620}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15489334, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16052071,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16141072, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19468303};
CC         IsoId=A2A432-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12465718};
CC         IsoId=A2A432-2; Sequence=VSP_039242;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- PTM: Neddylated. Deneddylated via its interaction with the COP9
CC       signalosome (CSN) complex (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13620}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cullin family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00330}.

RN   [5]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 1-12; 42-49; 61-68 AND 215-224, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6, and OF1; TISSUE=Brain, and Hippocampus;
RA   Lubec G., Kang S.U., Sunyer B., Chen W.-Q.;
RL   Submitted (JAN-2009) to UniProtKB.
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH KRT17, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE
RP   SPECIFICITY, AND INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=16710422; DOI=10.1038/nature04659;
RA   Kim S., Wong P., Coulombe P.A.;
RT   "A keratin cytoskeletal protein regulates protein synthesis and
RT   epithelial cell growth.";
RL   Nature 441:362-365(2006).
RN   [7]
RP   INTERACTION WITH SAMSN1.
RX   PubMed=20478393; DOI=10.1016/j.biocel.2010.05.004;
RA   Brandt S., Ellwanger K., Beuter-Gunia C., Schuster M., Hausser A.,
RA   Schmitz I., Beer-Hammer S.;
RT   "SLy2 targets the nuclear SAP30/HDAC1 complex.";
RL   Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 42:1472-1481(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Adapter protein implicated in the regulation of a large
CC       spectrum of both general and specialized signaling pathways. Binds
CC       to a large number of partners, usually by recognition of a
CC       phosphoserine or phosphothreonine motif. Binding generally results
CC       in the modulation of the activity of the binding partner. When
CC       bound to KRT17, regulates protein synthesis and epithelial cell
CC       growth by stimulating Akt/mTOR pathway. May also regulate MDM2
CC       autoubiquitination and degradation and thereby activate p53/TP53.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16710422}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Found in a complex with XPO7, EIF4A1, ARHGAP1,
CC       VPS26A, VPS29, VPS35 and SFN. Interacts with GAB2 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with KRT17. Interacts with SAMSN1. Interacts with SRPK2
CC       (By similarity). Interacts with COPS6 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with RFWD2; this interaction leads to proteasomal degradation (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9QWL7:Krt17; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1544118, EBI-309015;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16710422}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16710422}. Secreted {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=May be secreted by a non-classical secretory pathway.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the basal layer of skin
CC       epithelium and in outer root sheath of hair follicle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16710422}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced in damaged or stressed epidermis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16710422}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated. Ubiquitination by RFFL induces proteasomal
CC       degradation and indirectly regulates p53/TP53 activation (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: 14-3-3 proteins have been shown to be PKC
CC       activators, but this effect could be non-specific and only due to
CC       the acidic nature of the protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 14-3-3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Liver;

RN   [8]
RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-181, AND IDENTIFICATION BY
RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=23576753; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1302961110;
RA   Rardin M.J., Newman J.C., Held J.M., Cusack M.P., Sorensen D.J.,
RA   Li B., Schilling B., Mooney S.D., Kahn C.R., Verdin E., Gibson B.W.;
RT   "Label-free quantitative proteomics of the lysine acetylome in
RT   mitochondria identifies substrates of SIRT3 in metabolic pathways.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 110:6601-6606(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the reversible transfer of the terminal
CC       phosphate group between ATP and AMP. Plays an important role in
CC       cellular energy homeostasis and in adenine nucleotide metabolism.
CC       Adenylate kinase activity is critical for regulation of the
CC       phosphate utilization and the AMP de novo biosynthesis pathways.
CC       Plays a key role in hematopoiesis. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03168}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + AMP = 2 ADP. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03168}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03168}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion intermembrane space
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03168}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTP6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTP6-2; Sequence=VSP_036504;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Present in the inner ear. Not detected in the
CC       vestibule at any developmental stage. Present at high level in the
CC       cochlea uniquely in the stria vascularis at postnatal day 7 but
CC       not at birth. Present within the lumen of the stria vascularis
CC       capillaries. Not detected in the capillaries or vessels of the
CC       adjacent connective tissue (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19043416}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Consists of three domains, a large central CORE domain and
CC       two small peripheral domains, NMPbind and LID, which undergo
CC       movements during catalysis. The LID domain closes over the site of
CC       phosphoryl transfer upon ATP binding. Assembling and dissambling
CC       the active center during each catalytic cycle provides an
CC       effective means to prevent ATP hydrolysis. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03168}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adenylate kinase family. AK2 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03168}.

RA   Walkowicz M., Ji Y., Ren X., Horsthemke B., Russell L.B., Johnson D.,

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-1578, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that regulates ubiquitin-
CC       dependent retention of repair proteins on damaged chromosomes.
CC       Recruited to sites of DNA damage in response to ionizing radiation
CC       (IR) and facilitates the assembly of UBE2N and RNF8 promoting DNA
CC       damage-induced formation of 'Lys-63'-linked ubiquitin chains. Acts
CC       as a mediator of binding specificity between UBE2N and RNF8.
CC       Involved in the maintenance of RNF168 levels. E3 ubiquitin-protein
CC       ligase that promotes the ubiquitination and proteasomal
CC       degradation of XPA which influences the circadian oscillation of
CC       DNA excision repair activity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (when phosphorylated at Thr-4829 and
CC       sumoylated) with RNF8 (via FHA domain); this interaction increases
CC       after ionising radiation (IR) treatment. Interacts with XPA (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with NEURL4. Via its interaction with
CC       NEURL4, may indirectly interact with CCP110 and CEP97 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, microtubule organizing center, centrosome, centriole
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Note=Recruited to sites of
CC       DNA damage in response to ionising radiation (IR) via its
CC       interaction with RNF8. May loose association with centrosomes
CC       during mitosis. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9689098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9949213};
CC         IsoId=Q4U2R1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15489334};
CC         IsoId=Q4U2R1-2; Sequence=VSP_051975;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highest levels are found in brain and testis
CC       with lower levels in heart, lung, liver, skeletal muscle and
CC       kidney. Little expression detected in spleen.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9689098}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The ZZ-type zinc finger mediates binding to SUMO1, and at
CC       lowe level SUMO2. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RCC1 repeats are grouped into three seven-bladed beta-
CC       propeller regions. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Thr-4829 is required for interaction with
CC       RNF8.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylated with SUMO1 by PIAS4 in response to double-strand
CC       breaks (DSBs), promoting the interaction with RNF8. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Defects in Herc2 are the cause of the runty, jerky,
CC       sterile phenotype (rjs), also known as the juvenile development
CC       and fertility phenotype (jfd2), which is characterized by reduced
CC       size, jerky gait, fertility problems including spermatocyte and
CC       oocyte abnormalities, defective maternal behavior and reduced
CC       lifespan with juvenile lethality. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10441737,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9689098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9949213}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 cytochrome b5 heme-binding domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00279}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 DOC domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00614}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 HECT (E6AP-type E3 ubiquitin-protein
CC       ligase) domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00104}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 MIB/HERC2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00749}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 21 RCC1 repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00235}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 ZZ-type zinc finger. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00228}.

RN   [9]
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 733-818.
RX   PubMed=17600150; DOI=10.1110/ps.072792007;
RA   Doi-Katayama Y., Hayashi F., Inoue M., Yabuki T., Aoki M., Seki E.,
RA   Matsuda T., Kigawa T., Yoshida M., Shirouzu M., Terada T.,
RA   Hayashizaki Y., Yokoyama S., Hirota H.;
RT   "Solution structure of the general transcription factor 2I domain in
RT   mouse TFII-I protein.";
RL   Protein Sci. 16:1788-1792(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Interacts with the basal transcription machinery by
CC       coordinating the formation of a multiprotein complex at the C-FOS
CC       promoter, and linking specific signal responsive activator
CC       complexes. Promotes the formation of stable high-order complexes
CC       of SRF and PHOX1 and interacts cooperatively with PHOX1 to promote
CC       serum-inducible transcription of a reporter gene deriven by the C-
CC       FOS serum response element (SRE). Acts as a coregulator for USF1
CC       by binding independently two promoter elements, a pyrimidine-rich
CC       initiator (Inr) and an upstream E-box (By similarity). Required
CC       for the formation of functional ARID3A DNA-binding complexes and
CC       for activation of immunoglobulin heavy-chain transcription upon B-
CC       lymphocyte activation. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16738337}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (Potential). Interacts with SRF and PHOX1.
CC       Binds a pyrimidine-rich initiator (Inr) and a recognition site (E-
CC       box) for upstream stimulatory factor 1 (USF1). Associates with the
CC       PH domain of Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) (By similarity). May
CC       be a component of a BHC histone deacetylase complex that contains
CC       HDAC1, HDAC2, HMG20B/BRAF35, KDM1A, RCOR1/CoREST, PHF21A/BHC80,
CC       ZMYM2, ZNF217, ZMYM3, GSE1 and GTF2I. Interacts with BTK and
CC       ARID3A. Interacts with isoform beta of PRKG1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus. Note=Colocalizes with
CC       BTK in the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Gamma;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Beta, Long;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-2; Sequence=VSP_003869;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-3; Sequence=VSP_003870;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=Delta, Short;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-4; Sequence=VSP_003869, VSP_003872;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-5; Sequence=VSP_003871;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=Alpha;
CC         IsoId=Q9ESZ8-6; Sequence=VSP_003872;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitous.
CC   -!- PTM: Transiently phosphorylated on tyrosine residues by BTK in
CC       response to B-cell receptor stimulation. Phosphorylation on Tyr-
CC       248 and Tyr-398, and perhaps, on Tyr-503 contributes to BTK-
CC       mediated transcriptional activation (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TFII-I family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00484}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 6 GTF2I-like repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00484}.

RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=16620771; DOI=10.1016/j.abb.2006.03.014;
RA   Agarwal A.K., Barnes R.I., Garg A.;
RT   "Functional characterization of human 1-acylglycerol-3-phosphate
RT   acyltransferase isoform 8: cloning, tissue distribution, gene
RT   structure, and enzymatic activity.";

RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=17675553; DOI=10.1182/blood-2007-04-086827;
RA   Wang C., Faloon P.W., Tan Z., Lv Y., Zhang P., Ge Y., Deng H.,
RA   Xiong J.-W.;
RT   "Mouse lysocardiolipin acyltransferase controls the development of
RT   hematopoietic and endothelial lineages during in vitro embryonic stem-
RT   cell differentiation.";
RL   Blood 110:3601-3609(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acyl-CoA:lysocardiolipin acyltransferase. Possesses both
CC       lysophosphatidylinositol acyltransferase (LPIAT) and
CC       lysophosphatidylglycerol acyltransferase (LPGAT) activities.
CC       Recognizes both monolysocardiolipin and dilysocardiolipin as
CC       substrates with a preference for linoleoyl-CoA and oleoyl-CoA as
CC       acyl donors. Acts as a remodeling enzyme for cardiolipin, a major
CC       membrane polyglycerophospholipid. Converts lysophosphatidic acid
CC       (LPA) into phosphatidic acid (PA) with a relatively low activity.
CC       Required for establishment of the hematopoietic and endothelial
CC       lineages. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15152008,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17675553}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Acyl-CoA + 1-acyl-sn-glycerol 3-phosphate =
CC       CoA + 1,2-diacyl-sn-glycerol 3-phosphate.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15152008}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Phospholipid metabolism; CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis;
CC       CDP-diacylglycerol from sn-glycerol 3-phosphate: step 2/3.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15152008}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15152008}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed with highest expression in
CC       heart, liver and E12.5 aorta-gonad-mesonephros and lower levels in
CC       the E16 fetal liver and adult bone marrow. In bone marrow, highest
CC       levels are found in B-cells compared with whole bone marrow, T-
CC       cells, erythrocytes, and granulocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15152008, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16620771,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17675553}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The HXXXXD motif is essential for acyltransferase activity
CC       and may constitute the binding site for the phosphate moiety of
CC       the glycerol-3-phosphate. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 1-acyl-sn-glycerol-3-phosphate
CC       acyltransferase family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=19131326; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M800451-MCP200;
RA   Sweet S.M., Bailey C.M., Cunningham D.L., Heath J.K., Cooper H.J.;
RT   "Large scale localization of protein phosphorylation by use of
RT   electron capture dissociation mass spectrometry.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 8:904-912(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytoskeletal protein required for organization of normal
CC       actin cytoskeleton. Roles in establishing cell morphology,
CC       motility, cell adhesion and cell-extracellular matrix interactions
CC       in a variety of cell types. May function as a scaffolding molecule
CC       with the potential to influence both actin polymerization and the
CC       assembly of existing actin filaments into higher-order arrays.
CC       Binds to proteins that bind to either monomeric or filamentous
CC       actin. Localizes at sites where active actin remodeling takes
CC       place, such as lamellipodia and membrane ruffles. Different
CC       isoforms may have functional differences. Involved in the control
CC       of morphological and cytoskeletal changes associated with
CC       dendritic cell maturation. Involved in targeting ACTN to specific
CC       May be required for the initiation of neural tube closure.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15950489,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16492705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17115415}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with ACTN, ARGBP2, LPP, PFN1, SPIN90, SRC and
CC       EZR (By similarity). Interacts with EPS8, LASP1 and VASP.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14983521,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16492705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16868024}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874}. Cell junction, focal adhesion
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874}. Cell projection, ruffle
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874}. Cell projection, lamellipodium
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874}. Cytoplasm, myofibril, sarcomere, Z
CC       line {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874}. Note=Localizes to stress
CC       fibers and Z lines.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=200 kDa isoform;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-2; Sequence=VSP_027934, VSP_027935, VSP_027936;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=90 kDa isoform, 3Ig isoform;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-3; Sequence=VSP_027932, VSP_027935;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=140 kDa isoform, 4Ig isoform;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-4; Sequence=VSP_027933, VSP_027935;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-5; Sequence=VSP_027931;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=6;
CC         IsoId=Q9ET54-6; Sequence=VSP_027935;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in both muscle and non-muscle tissues
CC       and cells (at protein level). Isoform 3 is widely expressed,
CC       isoform 4 is particularly abundant in tissues rich in smooth
CC       muscle and in the cardiac muscle and isoform 1 is detected in
CC       heart. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11438925}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Ubiquitously detected in embryonic tissues,
CC       and down-regulated in certain adult tissues (at protein level).
CC       Isoform 3 is widely expressed in embryonic tissues (at protein
CC       level). In adults is detected in spleen and gut, and is almost
CC       undetectable in heart, skeletal muscle, liver, and kidney (at
CC       protein level). Isoform 4 is widely expressed in neonatal tissues
CC       (brain, heart, lung, stomach, intestine, kidney, bone and skin)
CC       (at protein level). Late in development expression is restricted
CC       to cardiac muscle and to organs rich in smooth muscle (at protein
CC       level). Isoform 1 is detected in neonatal striated muscle and
CC       bone, and remains highly expressed in adult skeletal and cardiac
CC       muscle (at protein level). Adult brain express an isoform of 80-85
CC       kDa. At E8.5 is mainly expressed the rostral and caudal part of
CC       neural plate. No expression is detected in somite. At E9.5 and
CC       E10.5 is ubiquitously detected. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931874,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15950489}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated predominantly on serines and, to a lesser
CC       extent, on tyrosines. Phosphorylation at Ser-1143 by PKB/AKT1
CC       modulates cytoskeletal organization and cell motility (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Death around E15.5 due to severe neural tube
CC       closure defects and herniation of liver and intestine. Palld-
CC       deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts display disorganized actin
CC       cytoskeleton, decreased polymerized filament actin, and decreased
CC       cell adhesion and compromised cell spreading on various
CC       extracellular matrix. Mice embryos lacking Palld exhibit defects
CC       in erythropoiesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15950489,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17115415, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17431131}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the myotilin/palladin family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 5 Ig-like C2-type (immunoglobulin-like)
CC       domains. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AK031696; Type=Frameshift; Positions=821; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAB26871.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: A number of straight-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenases
CC       of different substrate specificities are present in mammalian
CC       tissues.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the acyl-CoA dehydrogenase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
